text: <@U02E3CRMA> <@U1172PRDX> Would love your eyes on this list to see if I missed anything

just went over the list real quick. wonder if we need: hub set up, user puts wine into the system, exchange a cap (place a new one on the bottle if battery is about to run out on existing one) 

?

:slightly_smiling_face:

Hey Felix, I was trying to capture specific moments of interaction that had direct hardware feedback (i.e. something lights up). I’ll cross check your suggestions with what I have there--thanks for the thoughts!
Do we think that hub set up has more interaction moments than what I’ve captured as numbers 2 and 3 in that first section?
Joel can answer the hub question

Hey there - I was just peeking at the Interaction Model list (which looks great BTW). 

I know this is MVP definition, but one thing I wondered about is if we should maybe capture non-ideal possible interactions that could happen. If this list captures what we hope to build for MVP, is it worth at least listing out what might NOT work? 

That could be user error, system malfunction beyond what's listed in error states, etc.

i believe the intention of elise's doc was to capture things that the user sees/directly interacts with. are you looking for a collected list of system level problems that we would need to account for behind the scenes?
right now i think we've been focusing on "happy path" but want to make sure that i understand you and that we're covering our bases

Gotcha. The error states may already capture more than I was thinking. But I'm thinking of things like user twists cap but not in the right direction (making this up). Is there any error state that captures something close to happy path but off JUST enough to require some mode of coaching/feedback.

Which I know is a rabbit hole that we can't answer every little thing for. As I read through this great list though, that was my one question. 

A question, by the way, that could very easily be answered with — this is the right fidelity for where we need to be right now. :wink:
no this is good to poke and prod! i just wanted to make sure i was thinking in the same head space
we can drill down 1 level and see if it starts leading us on many different branches
cool. I'll defer to Marce for how far down such a path is useful, but it was in my head. Appreciated and thanks for sharing all of this!

Yes. Because it's always plugged in, has a cloud connection, and more state to maintain (e.g. wifi connection, system health, user presence, etc) the hub can potentially show more information on the LED ring for instance.

Then again, if we're assuming the hub isn't required to be visible, that level of interaction/information may be too much and undermine the idea that it's all supplementary info.

Thanks for those thoughts <@U0265G76F>. I was initially thinking specifically about hardware feedback as it relates to the “most-common” interactions, but I think it would be a good idea to capture the non-ideal possible interactions as well. I’ll add that as a section while continuing to put my initial effort towards expanding the ideal-path interactions. Thanks!

I also think that some of the user error scenarios will come from a better understanding of the physical mechanisms of the hardware. Questions like “can the cap physically turn the wrong way?” or “could a user place the hub in the wrong spot?” might be answered later down the road once we nail down more the the hardware requirements. This is not to say we shouldn’t capture them now, just another thought
